Notes: The Afghan Govt. ordered school reopenings to proceed for all levels of education starting on the week of Oct 4. This is reported by at least two different sources:  - Afghanistan Times on Oct 4: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108194853/http://www.afghanistantimes.af/schools-reopen-after-covid-19-closings/  - Anadolu Agency (a Turkish run news organization) Oct 3: https://web.archive.org/web/20201026120914/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/asia-pacific/covid-19-afghanistan-finally-reopens-all-schools/1994551    As reported by the Afghanistan Times on Oct 4: "The schools were planned to resume for students below 10th grade but a Cabinet’s recent decision confirmed reopening for 11th and 12th graders as well. Ministry of Education says schools will reopen from October 3rd to late December in cold areas will close early January for winter recess till early March."

No change in policy, schools remain fully opened until beginning of Winter break early December. That being said, primary schools will be closing earlier due to the cold weather (non-covid related)    https://web.archive.org/web/20201120092607/http://www.afghanistantimes.af/ministry-to-close-schools-next-week-due-to-severe-cold-weather/

No government mandated restrictions seem to be in place since lock down restrictions started easing in Afghanistan.    According to news reports (https://web.archive.org/web/20201108205026/https://apnews.com/article/399dd046ff9c9f5693210d60f58b55ab):     "Desperate for relief from endless war combined with the pandemic, Afghans are rushing back to public recreation as the government eases the lockdown it imposed to fight the coronavirus. Since mid-July, Afghans can once again frequent parks, swimming pools and gyms, shop in malls and celebrate marriages in wedding halls. Universities and private schools have reopened, and at government schools, the 11th and 12th grades have restarted.     Few wear masks or take other precaution — and authorities are left trying to remind the public of the danger of a second wave of the pandemic."

No change in previous policy, no restrictions apply.    Official webpage of the Danish embassy in Afghanistan states no specific restrictions due to Covid    https://web.archive.org/web/20201120094201/https://afghanistan.um.dk/en/travel%20and%20residence/nycoronavirus-covid19/

Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? No    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026123507/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Note: there seems to be some interest in testing travelers coming in from Iran and Pakistan, but there does not seem to concrete details on what such measures might entail, and if/how they were implemented. Examples:  - (best viewed with Google Translate) https://web.archive.org/web/20201108202749/https://moph.gov.af/dr/%D8%A8%D9%87-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%B7%D8%B1-%D8%AC%D9%84%D9%88%DA%AF%DB%8C%D8%B1%DB%8C-%D8%A7%D8%B2-%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AA%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%A8%DB%8C%D8%B4%D8%AA%D8%B1-%D9%88%DB%8C%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B3-%DA%A9%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%86%D8%A7-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D9%88%D9%84%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AA%E2%80%8C%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%87%D9%85-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%B2-%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%88-%D9%BE%D8%A7%DA%A9%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AA%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%A8%DB%8C%D8%B1-%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85

According to the UK foreign office:    "Everyone arriving in Afghanistan needs to have their temperature checked at the airport. If your temperature is high, the government will advise you to quarantine and will offer you medical attention at two hospitals in Kabul."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201120094516/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/afghanistan/entry-requirements
No change to previous entry, no financial (income) support available/announced.
No official public campaign. Some politicans frequently warn about the dangers of Covid however.

"Testing is generally available at designated COVID-19 hospitals, including the Afghan Japan Hospital. Tests are free of charge, however results may take a week or longer.  Private facilities, including the City Hospital in Kabul, are generally able to provide same-day results."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201026123507/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Previous entry still applies:    "Testing is generally available at designated COVID-19 hospitals, including the Afghan Japan Hospital. Tests are free of charge, however results may take a week or longer.  Private facilities, including the City Hospital in Kabul, are generally able to provide same-day results."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201026123507/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Followed the given links from previous entries but could not find any information on contact tracing. That being said, this does not mean that contact tracing is not available

"Afghanistan on Monday made the use of face masks mandatory in public places across the country in a bid to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus.  Speaking at a news conference in the capital Kabul, Ahmad Jawad Osmani, Afghanistan’s acting health minister, said the virus situation in the country is “satisfactory” compared to neighboring countries."

As indicated by the UNESCO 'Global Monitoring of School Closures caused by COVID-19' all schools in Bangladesh remain closed due to the continued coronavirus escalation. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201109160237/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

AlJazeera Nov 13: "Bangladesh has extended its closure of schools and educational institutions, which were last open in March, until December 19. The government closed schools and educational institutions on March 17 and has extended the closure several times, most recently until November 15."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122211406/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/11/13/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave

Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  - Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  - Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  - No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  - Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  - Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  - Residents must work from home.  - Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.  - COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  - Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centres will be closed.  - No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  - Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  - Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      IN GENERAL: Workplace restrictions seem be removed.  Dhaka Tribune: "On October 31, the Cabinet Division sent notices to all public offices of the country, asking them to restrict entry and to refuse service to anyone without a mask. The notice further said masks have been made compulsory for all offices, courts, shopping malls, bazaars, state or government buildings and social events."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122215536/https://www.dhakatribune.com/health/coronavirus/2020/11/02/no-restriction-on-public-movement-to-curb-second-wave-of-covid-19    Nov 12, reuters.com: "“The decision has been taken considering the second wave... We can’t play with the lives of our children,” said a senior official of the education ministry, who declined to be named. **The government however, has lifted most other restrictions**"  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122212335if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bangladesh-educati/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave-idUSKBN27S26A

Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    It is important to note GoB officials have confirmed that the list of Red zones does not mean the areas are or will be under lockdown restrictions.    Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  - Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  - Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  - No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  - Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  - Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  - Residents must work from home.  - Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.  - COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  - Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centres will be closed.  - No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  - Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  - Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      IN GENERAL: COVID19-related restrictions seem be removed, although with strict adherence to mask wearing.  Dhaka Tribune: "On October 31, the Cabinet Division sent notices to all public offices of the country, asking them to restrict entry and to refuse service to anyone without a mask. The notice further said masks have been made compulsory for all offices, courts, shopping malls, bazaars, state or government buildings and **social events**."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122215536/https://www.dhakatribune.com/health/coronavirus/2020/11/02/no-restriction-on-public-movement-to-curb-second-wave-of-covid-19    Nov 12, reuters.com: "“The decision has been taken considering the second wave... We can’t play with the lives of our children,” said a senior official of the education ministry, who declined to be named. **The government however, has lifted most other restrictions**"  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122212335if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bangladesh-educati/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave-idUSKBN27S26A

Flights from certain countries are banned at this time:    US Embassy, Bangladesh website:  Wayback snapshot Nov 11 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  Updated Nov 18 2020; Wayback snapshot Nov 22, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    "The Government of Bangladesh has authorized the resumption of limited international commercial flights.  International flights to/from Bahrain, China, India, Malaysia, Maldives, Oman, Qatar, Sri Lanka, Turkey, U.A.E. and the U.K. are permitted to operate.    To avoid the further spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Civil Aviation Authority of Bangladesh announced until further notice all international commercial passenger flights from Bhutan, Hong Kong, Kuwait, Nepal, and Thailand shall not be allowed to land at any airport in Bangladesh."    Additionally, most passengers landing in Bangladesh via flights must have a COVID-19 negative certificate irrespective of where their place of departure.    "If international travelers arrive in Bangladesh with COVID-19 symptoms, they will be institutionally quarantined for 14 days.  If international travelers arrive in Bangladesh with no COVID-19 symptoms, they will be required to “home quarantine” for 14 days."

26th October 2020, Bangladesh's government has launched a ‘no mask, no service’ policy in order to fight the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Cabinet Secretary informed that the people at all the social institutions, public and private offices, shopping malls, haat-bazaars, mosques or other places of worship throughout the country, educational institutions must wear a mask because of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026194022/https://www.jagranjosh.com/current-affairs/bangladesh-government-orders-no-mask-no-service-policy-to-curb-covid-19-1603713647-1
No change in previous policy
No change in previous policy

1. All social events are discouraged. Unavoidable ones should be limited to family members.  2. Cremation and funeral rites, and other rituals at home are permitted but without gathering.  3. Official meetings, seminars, workshops and travels are not allowed.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201108001020/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/    1. Sports facilities like gym, yoga, dance studios and rubber tracks can operate at 50 percent capacity.    2. Non-contact sports of athletics and golf, and partial contact sports of badminton, tennis and table tennis are allowed.    3. Given the engagement for fitness among people, all futsal, football turfs and basketball courts, including private, can operate. However, there should not be any spectators at any time.    4. Archery may be played, subject to not more than 15 participants. No spectators are allowed.    5. The business closure time of 9pm will not apply to sports.    6. Parks and public places can open with strict monitoring of crowd.

27th October 2020, Unlock 5 guidelines issued in Sept to remain in force till Nov 30.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201030083211/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/covid-19-unlock-5-guidelines-issued-in-sept-to-remain-in-force-till-nov-30/articleshow/78890760.cms

The Union government has permitted the reopening of schools in phases after October 15. However, the actual timing and manner of reopening will be decided by individual states.  Unlock 5.0 guidelines issued, would remain in force till November 30.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110100342/https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/schools-reopening-india-guidelines-rules-coronavirus-pandemic-quixplained-explained-6801654/
No change in policy found.

Due to surging daily Covid-19 cases, Haryana on 21 November announced closure of schools until 30 November, while Mumbai, Thane, Navi Mumbai and Panvel directed all schools to shut until the end of the year. In Maharashtra, only students of grade 9 and 12 are allowed to go to schools.    https://archive.vn/hRicc

Night curfew between 10pm and 6am came into effect from 21 November until further notice in five districts - Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior, Ratlam ad Vidisha.    https://archive.vn/hRicc

27th October 2020, The government has now decided to make a graded relaxation in visa and travel restrictions for more categories of foreign nationals and Indian nationals who wish to enter or leave India. Under this graded relaxation, the government has decided to restore with immediate effect all existing visas, except electronic visa, tourist visa and medical visa, the statement said. All international travellers will, however, have to strictly adhere to the guidelines of the Union Health Ministry regarding quarantine and other health/COVID-19 matters. Earlier, the Health Ministry issued a set of guidelines for international arrival as per which all travellers should submit a self-declaration form on the website of Delhi airport at least 72 hours before the scheduled travel.     India has so far established air bubbles arrangements with Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bahrain, Oman, Canada, France, Germany, Iraq, Japan, Maldives, Nigeria, Qatar, the UAE, Kenya, Ukraine, Bhutan, the UK, and the US.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201030085828if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/who-all-can-fly-abroad-and-which-countries-from-india-new-international-travel-rules-here-11603676272956.html

10th Nov 2020, as of now, international flight operations shall remain suspended till 30 November 2020.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201110125613/https://www.skyscanner.co.in/news/corona-virus-information

On Nov 2 news agencies (Dinamina, a Sinhala language daily newspaper in Sri Lanka; and the AP) reported that the Ministry of Education in Sri Lanka decided to postpone the school reopenings that were scheduled for Nov 9.    According to Dinamina (translated from Sinhala using Google Translate). "The Ministry of Education has decided to postpone the commencement of schools for the third term by another two weeks today (02)." - https://web.archive.org/web/20201115195244/http://www.dinamina.lk/2020/11/02/%E0%B6%B4%E0%B7%94%E0%B7%80%E0%B6%AD%E0%B7%8A/108140/%E0%B6%B4%E0%B7%8F%E0%B7%83%E0%B7%90%E0%B6%BD%E0%B7%8A-%E0%B6%86%E0%B6%BB%E0%B6%B8%E0%B7%8A%E0%B6%B7%E0%B6%BA-%E0%B6%AD%E0%B7%80%E0%B6%AD%E0%B7%8A-%E0%B7%83%E0%B6%AD%E0%B7%92-%E0%B6%AF%E0%B7%99%E0%B6%9A%E0%B6%9A%E0%B6%A7-%E0%B6%9A%E0%B6%BD%E0%B7%8A%E0%B6%BA%E0%B6%BA%E0%B7%92    This is corroborated by lankaeducation.com, a local Sri Lankan blog that tracks the state of education in the country: "Reopening of Sri Lanka government schools to be postponed due to present coronavirus spike situation in the country, according to ministry of education sources. Education Ministry secretary, Prof Kapila Perera has told to “Silumina newspaper” that due to the outbreak of COVID19, schools cannot be reopened as scheduled. Schools were scheduled to reopen on 9 November. Sri Lanka Schools Reopening Delay." (Silumina newspaper is a sister weekly news outfit to Dinamina). - https://web.archive.org/web/20201115200254/https://www.lankaeducation.com/sri-lanka-schools-reopening-delay-2/    Further, according to an AP report re-circulated by ABCNews: "Schools had been scheduled to reopen Nov. 9, but the government announced Tuesday that classes would not resume until Nov. 23." - https://web.archive.org/web/20201115200106/https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/latest-indias-coronavirus-cases-continue-daily-decline-73965144

On Nov 9, according to an AP new report, "The government said the coronavirus threat hasn’t subsided, but the region must be opened up because the economy can’t sustain a continued closure."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115204723/https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-sri-lanka-asia-arrests-colombo-0511a1a54f569364f2e8bdb901f42c79

On Nov 9, according to an AP new report, "The government said the coronavirus threat hasn’t subsided, but the region must be opened up because the economy can’t sustain a continued closure."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115204723/https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-sri-lanka-asia-arrests-colombo-0511a1a54f569364f2e8bdb901f42c79

Pockets of Sri Lanka continue to be under lockdowns and isolation orders:     Sources:  - AP reported on Nov 09: "[...] the government lifted a curfew that had been in effect in the capital, Colombo, and its suburbs.. Only pockets where infections are high will remain under isolation with no one permitted to enter or leave the area.", https://web.archive.org/web/20201115204723/https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-sri-lanka-asia-arrests-colombo-0511a1a54f569364f2e8bdb901f42c79  - The Hindu, a daily newspaper in India reported on Nov 8, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115213247/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/coronavirus-sri-lanka-to-lift-capital-district-lockdown-on-monday/article33052113.ece  "“The curfew which was in force on the Western province will be lifted at 5 a.m. tomorrow”, Army Commander Shavendra Silva, who heads the national operations center to prevent COVID-19, said. However, Silva said that several areas in the province would still be under isolation.  The capital city and the adjoining Gampaha district was under quarantine curfew continuously over the last 10 days."

source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115211023/https://www.newsfirst.lk/2020/11/10/public-transport-services-operate-despite-low-passenger-numbers/    Public transportation was operating within the country, except for "isolated" regions.  "all buses were prepared for operation, however, only 10% was added to service due to low passenger numbers"  "Deputy General Manager of the Sri Lanka Transport Board A. H. Panduka said more than 2300 SLTB buses were deployed for operations, however, these buses did not operate inside isolated areas."  "Railways Superintendent W. D. R. Pathmalal said Sri Lanka Railways was able to operate all 136 Train Operations on Monday (09) for the benefit of the general public."  "Ascertain areas in Panadura are in lock-down, 12 new train operations will be introduced to transport passengers between Fort and Panadura"

Pockets of Sri Lanka continue to be under lockdowns and isolation orders:     Sources:  - AP reported on Nov 09: "[...] the government lifted a curfew that had been in effect in the capital, Colombo, and its suburbs.. Only pockets where infections are high will remain under isolation with no one permitted to enter or leave the area.", https://web.archive.org/web/20201115204723/https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-sri-lanka-asia-arrests-colombo-0511a1a54f569364f2e8bdb901f42c79  - The Hindu, a daily newspaper in India reported on Nov 8, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115213247/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/coronavirus-sri-lanka-to-lift-capital-district-lockdown-on-monday/article33052113.ece  "“The curfew which was in force on the Western province will be lifted at 5 a.m. tomorrow”, Army Commander Shavendra Silva, who heads the national operations center to prevent COVID-19, said. However, Silva said that several areas in the province would still be under isolation.  The capital city and the adjoining Gampaha district was under quarantine curfew continuously over the last 10 days."

Traveling in and out of industrial zones within the country seem to have targeted movement restrictions:  Nov 02, 2020: www.newsfirst.lk: "Sri Lanka Police introduced a Quarantine Curfew Pass application to be filled by those who require passes in order to resume operations at factories and other production centers"  sources:  - https://web.archive.org/web/20201115210122/https://www.newsfirst.lk/2020/11/02/quarantine-curfew-pass-application-for-industries-available-for-download/    other Govt. notices:  - https://covid19.gov.lk/news/economy/issuing-of-curfew-passes.html (WaybackMachine was returning a 502 error when archiving this website)  - https://covid19.gov.lk/news/economy/issuing-of-curfew-passes-export-processing-zones.html (WaybackMachine was returning a 502 error when archiving this website)    However, internal movements across Sri Lanka, in general, seem to have no other concrete measures.  On Nov 9, according to an AP new report, "Passenger trains resumed operating after nearly two weeks and the government lifted a curfew that had been in effect in the capital, Colombo, and its suburbs."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115204723/https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-sri-lanka-asia-arrests-colombo-0511a1a54f569364f2e8bdb901f42c79

As per the US Embassy in Sri Lanka: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115220421/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Quarantine Information:  All arriving passengers are required to undergo a mandatory 14-day quarantine followed by an at-home 14-day self-isolation.   COVID-19 Testing:    Visitors are required to show a negative PCR test, taken within 72 hours, prior to boarding a flight to Sri Lanka.  Upon arrival in Sri Lanka another PCR test will be done.  A third test will be required prior to release from quarantine.

It is reported on 5 November that, Nepal has reopened with restrictions to those seeking to climb or trek its famous peaks.    [Quote]  Rudra Singh Tamang, director general of Nepal’s Department of Tourism said:  “We are not opening the country for all visitors and only mountaineers and trekkers who have already had a permit taken prior permit will be allowed to come to Nepal.  “We are opening to a sector of visitors who we know we can handle and manage.”  [End of quote]    https://archive.vn/yDExY

No further policy update as of now on school reopening. However, Under the final phase of reopening of educational institutions, primary schools across Pakistan reopen from 30th September 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110093427/https://southasiamonitor.org/pakistan/primary-schools-reopen-today-pakistan

Reuters reported on Nov 26: "Pakistan shut its schools and postponed exams on Thursday [26th Nov] to try to curb new coronavirus infections and a rise in the number of people in hospital with COVID-19"; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129195316if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-pakistan-schools-idINKBN28618X    This lines up with reporting from Khaleej Times on Nov 23rd: "Pakistan will close down schools, colleges and universities from November 26 in a bid to contain the spread of Covid-19 pandemic. Shafqat Mahmood, Pakistan’s Education Minister, held a press conference on Monday [Nov 23 2020] to announce the details. He said online classes will continue from November 26 to December 24. The educational institutes will be closed from December 25, 2020 to January 10, 2021 for winter vacations." source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129194756/https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/rest-of-asia/covid-19-pakistan-announces-closure-of-schools-colleges-universities

9th Nov 2020, In view of a surge in coronavirus cases during the second wave of the viral disease in the country, the National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) issued new guidelines by allowing “work from home” for 50 per cent staff of public and private institutions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110094435/https://www.dawn.com/news/1589054

On Nov 24, 2020, Geo News TV provided a useful summary of COVID19 restrictions that show a patchwork of Workplace/educational/gathering restrictions across the country; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201909/https://www.geo.tv/latest/320263-what-are-the-covid-19-restrictions-in-pakistan    These restrictions across different parts of the country suggest governments at the local and state levels imposing targeted restrictions as and when appropriate for workplace restrictions. The strictest of them seem to start on Nov 20 2020, in Pakistan Administered Kashmir where a 15-day lockdown is in place (starting from Nov 20) -- this lockdown has prompted the 3T designation for C2.    In the order of strictness and how early such restrictions seem have come into effect:  1. "A 15-day lockdown has been imposed by the AJK (Azaad Kashmir, aka Pakistan Administered Kashmir) government since November 20. All businesses and offices are closed while the government offices will operate at 50% capacity. Only essential services are allowed with strict implementation of coronavirus SOPs."  2. "Sindh: Markets and business centres are to close by 6pm on weekdays. They can open by 6am, but have to stay closed on weekends, the Sindh home department notified on Monday. All cinemas, shrines, and gyms will be closed. Government and private offices can call in only 50% of staff to work, while the remaining employees are to work from home."  3. "Punjab: Smart lockdowns imposed in 6 cities: Bahawalpur, Bhakkar, Multan, Rawalpindi, Sargodha, and Lahore. All shopping malls, restaurants, offices (private and public) will remain closed in the areas under lockdown. Public and private offices throughout the (Punjab) province are to ensure that 50% of the staff works from home. This will be applicable till January 31, 2021."  4. "The Khyber Pakhtunkhwa government has issued no new coronavirus restrictions this week. Its home department issued SOPs to be followed last week which are still in place. All shopping malls, restaurants, shops, and marriage halls have been directed to shut by 10pm. Pharmacies, medical stores and tandoor shops (and Petrol Pumps and LPG shops) will remain open 24/7."    The details of the work place restrictions, esp. in Punjab and Sindh were also reported by Deccan Herald on Nov 24: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129202234if_/https://www.deccanherald.com/international/world-news-politics/pakistan-provincial-authorities-introduce-new-covid-19-restrictions-national-tally-reaches-379883-919348.html    In General though, on Nov 25 2020 the Pakistan Government (specifically the Prime Minister) has ruled out any broad nation-wide restrictions to contain COVID19: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129210523/https://in.news.yahoo.com/pak-pm-rules-closing-down-175707452.html

On Nov 24, 2020, Geo News TV provided a useful summary of COVID19 restrictions that show a patchwork of Workplace/educational/gathering restrictions across the country; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201909/https://www.geo.tv/latest/320263-what-are-the-covid-19-restrictions-in-pakistan    These restrictions across different parts of the country suggest governments at the local and state levels imposing targeted restrictions as and when appropriate for public events and gatherings. The local government in Pakistan Administered Kashmir, aka Azaad Kashmir, imposed a strict 15-day lockdown starting on Nov 20 2020. As per the Geo New article: "Public gatherings, including weddings, have been banned." Such reporting suggests that public events in targeted/specific regions within the country have be halted/banned.

9th Nov 2020, In view of a surge in coronavirus cases during the second wave of the viral disease in the country, the National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) issued new guidelines banning indoor marriages. Only outdoor marriages would be allowed with upper limit of 1000 persons. The ban will be enforced with effect from Nov 20 so that already arranged marriages at indoor venues can take place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110094435/https://www.dawn.com/news/1589054

Nov 16, 2020: More stringent restrictions will be implemented on Nov 20th in urban centers.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116020431/http://covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/07November2020_20201106_Additional_Guidelines_on_Marriage_Events_during_COVID_19_4505.pdf

Targeted lockdowns across the country are preventing public events or gatherings.  The local government in Pakistan Administered Kashmir, aka Azaad Kashmir, imposed a strict 15-day lockdown starting on Nov 20 2020. As per the Geo New article: "Public gatherings, including weddings, have been banned."  Similarly, in "Khyber Pakhtunkhwa: All major public gathering have been banned. Legal action will be taken in case of violations."   Such reporting suggests that public events in targeted/specific regions within the country have be halted/banned. source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201909/https://www.geo.tv/latest/320263-what-are-the-covid-19-restrictions-in-pakistan    In general, the Pakistan Government issued guidance on public gatherings such as weddings for crowd sizes as small as 25 people. Broadly such guidance suggests that "No indoor gatherings are permitted, and only outdoor wedding events are allowed, in which number of the guests must not exceed 300 individuals with mandatory arrangements for seating  of each individual at-least 6 feet apart. event timing should be restricted to 2 hours with closure evening timing at 10 PM" Source: https://covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/28November2020_20201127_Additional_Guidelines_for_Marriage_Events_Ceremonies_during_COVID_19_4505.pdf    Additionally, the guidelines provide clear space restrictions for specific crowd sizes. E.g. for a gathering of upto 25 people, there should be at least 900 sq feet of space; for crowds of upto 100 people a minimum of 3600 sq ft. is required.    While the guidance document is date Nov 27th 2020, it also states that "These guidelines will be implemented from 20th November 2020 onwards in urban centers (Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Rawalpindi, Multan, Hyderabad, Gilgit,  Muzaffarabad, Mirpur, Peshawar, Quetta, Gujranwala, Gujrat, Faisalabad, Bahawalpur & Swat)".

Transportation Options:    Are commercial flights operating? [Yes]  Is public transportation operating? [Yes]  According to the Government of Pakistan, individuals using public transportation – trains or buses – should wear facemasks and keep a distance of at least six feet from other individuals.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129214352/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Symptomatic travelers will be required to take a COVID-19 RT-PCR test and its results submitted to the designated Pakistani authorities within 48 hours of arrival. In cases found positive for COVID-19 based on a test upon arrival, travelers may be required to comply with isolation procedures.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129214352/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Nov 16, 2020: "Pakistan has considered to incorporate Ag-RDT in its testing strategy for disease  surveillance and screening."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201116022452/http://covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/05November2020_20201104_TESTING_STRATEGY_INCORPORATING_COVID-19_ANTIGEN_DETECTION_RAPID_DIAGNOSTIC_TESTS_5301.pdf

29th October 2020, The National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC), after continuous warnings of rising Covid-19 cases across the country, made it compulsory for all citizens to wear a face mask when stepping out of their homes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110093846/https://www.dawn.com/news/1587447

9th Nov 2020, In view of a surge in coronavirus cases during the second wave of the viral disease in the country, the National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) issued new guidelines by fixing Rs100 as fine for not wearing mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110094435/https://www.dawn.com/news/1589054
